creator.name: Sociëteit van Suriname
creator.his_func: Since the West India Company (WIC) was financially unable to take over Suriname from the States of Zeeland, the Society of Suriname was founded in May 1683. It was a triumvirate: the WIC participated alongside the city of Amsterdam and - until 1770 - the family Van Aerssen van Sommelsdijck. Chairman of the Society was always a representative of the city of Amsterdam. The Society was located in Amsterdam. The Society appointed a governor with the approval of the States-General. The States-General retained the supreme authority and contributed to the defence. Following the abolition of the WIC in 1791, the city of Amsterdam was the only participant. At the end of 1795 the Society was transferred to the Committee for the affairs of the colonies and possessions on the Guinea Coast and in America, abbreviated as the West India Committee.
